title: Are there any logical fallacies that are arguably not valid (Not the argument made, the actual fallacy itself such as 'Appeal to Authority'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Logical fallacies are categorically invalid, since they would not be logical fallacies otherwise. Presumably you are asking is: ‘Are there valid methods of reasoning that are alleged to be spurious?’ The answer to which is: ‘There are methods of reasoning that are not in general truth-preserving but that in special contexts can be truth-preserving and therefore non-fallacious.’ Consider the so-called fallacy of composition, this being the inference from ‘x parts have a given property’ to ‘x itself has that property.’ This method of reasoning is obviously spurious in many contexts. For example, ‘each of x’s limbs weighs less than 5 lbs; therefore x itself weighs less than 5 lbs.’ But it does hold in special contexts. For example, each of x’s parts weighs more than 5 lbs; therefore x itself weighs more than 5 lbs. When a given form of reasoning is described as a ‘logical fallacy’, what is meant is not that use of it is categorically spurious but is rather that use of it is not categorically non-spurious.
All logical fallacies are not valid.
